column1: Tumwater is a city in Thurston County
column4: 371 at the 2010 census. It is situated near where the Deschutes River enters Budd Inlet
column5: the southernmost point of Puget Sound; it also borders the state capital of Olympia to the north. Tumwater is the oldest permanent American settlement on Puget Sound.

column1: The site of Tumwater and Tumwater Falls has been home to Southern Lushootseed-speaking peoples known as the Steh-Chass / Stehchass or Statca'sabsh (a subtribe of the Sahewamish (Sahe'wabsh)
column2: an subgroup of the Nisqually people; who became part of the post-treaty Squaxin Island Tribe) for thousands of years. "Steh-Chass" is the Lushootseed name for Budd Inlet
column3: Deschutes River and the Tumwater Falls area
column4: and for an important village of the Statca'sabsh.

column1: Tumwater was originally called "New Market" by American settlers
column2: and under the latter name was platted in 1845. The present name is derived from Chinook Jargon and means "waterfall". A post office called Tumwater was established in 1863. The city incorporated in 1875.
-122.911074). Its northern neighbor is the state capital of Olympia.
